framework.name: NIST Cybersecurity Framework 2.0
framework.description: The NIST Cybersecurity Framework (CSF) 2.0 provides a comprehensive set of outcomes that can help organizations manage and reduce their cybersecurity risks. It integrates industry standards and best practices to help organizations manage cybersecurity risks.

functions.name: Govern
functions.description: The organization's cybersecurity risk management strategy, expectations, and policy are established, communicated, and monitored. The GOVERN Function provides outcomes to inform what an organization may do to achieve and prioritize the outcomes of the other five Functions in the context of its mission and stakeholder expectations.

categories.name: Organizational Context
categories.description: The circumstances — mission, stakeholder expectations, dependencies, and legal, regulatory, and contractual requirements — surrounding the organization's cybersecurity risk management decisions are understood.

subcategories.outcome: The organizational mission is understood and informs cybersecurity risk management
Internal and external stakeholders are understood, and their needs and expectations regarding cybersecurity risk management are understood and considered
Legal, regulatory, and contractual requirements regarding cybersecurity — including privacy and civil liberties obligations — are understood and managed
Critical objectives, capabilities, and services that external stakeholders depend on or expect from the organization are understood and communicated
Outcomes, capabilities, and services that the organization depends on are understood and communicated

categories.name: Oversight
categories.description: Results of organization-wide cybersecurity risk management activities and performance are used to inform, improve, and adjust the risk management strategy.

subcategories.outcome: Cybersecurity risk management strategy outcomes are reviewed to inform and adjust strategy and direction
The cybersecurity risk management strategy is reviewed and adjusted to ensure coverage of organizational requirements and risks
Organizational cybersecurity risk management performance is evaluated and reviewed for adjustments needed

categories.name: Policy
categories.description: Organizational cybersecurity policy is established, communicated, and enforced.

subcategories.outcome: Policy for managing cybersecurity risks is established based on organizational context, cybersecurity strategy, and priorities and is communicated and enforced
Policy for managing cybersecurity risks is reviewed, updated, communicated, and enforced to reflect changes in requirements, threats, technology, and organizational mission

categories.name: Risk Management Strategy
categories.description: The organization's priorities, constraints, risk tolerance and appetite statements, and assumptions are established, communicated, and used to support operational risk decisions.

subcategories.outcome: Risk management objectives are established and agreed to by organizational stakeholders
Risk appetite and risk tolerance statements are established, communicated, and maintained
Cybersecurity risk management activities and outcomes are included in enterprise risk management processes
Strategic direction that describes appropriate risk response options is established and communicated
Lines of communication across the organization are established for cybersecurity risks, including risks from suppliers and other third parties
A standardized method for calculating, documenting, categorizing, and prioritizing cybersecurity risks is established and communicated
Strategic opportunities (i.e., positive risks) are characterized and are included in organizational cybersecurity risk discussions

categories.name: Roles, Responsibilities, and Authorities
categories.description: Cybersecurity roles, responsibilities, and authorities to foster accountability, performance assessment, and continuous improvement are established and communicated.

subcategories.outcome: Organizational leadership is responsible and accountable for cybersecurity risk and fosters a culture that is risk-aware, ethical, and continually improving
Roles, responsibilities, and authorities related to cybersecurity risk management are established, communicated, understood, and enforced
Adequate resources are allocated commensurate with the cybersecurity risk strategy, roles, responsibilities, and policies
Cybersecurity is included in human resources practices

categories.name: Cybersecurity Supply Chain Risk Management
categories.description: Cyber supply chain risk management processes are identified, established, managed, monitored, and improved by organizational stakeholders.

subcategories.outcome: A cybersecurity supply chain risk management program, strategy, objectives, policies, and processes are established and agreed to by organizational stakeholders
Cybersecurity roles and responsibilities for suppliers, customers, and partners are established, communicated, and coordinated internally and externally
Cybersecurity supply chain risk management is integrated into cybersecurity and enterprise risk management, risk assessment, and improvement processes
Suppliers are known and prioritized by criticality
Requirements to address cybersecurity risks in supply chains are established, prioritized, and integrated into contracts and other types of agreements with suppliers and other relevant third parties
Planning and due diligence are performed to reduce risks before entering into formal supplier or other third-party relationships
The risks posed by a supplier, their products and services, and other third parties are understood, recorded, prioritized, assessed, responded to, and monitored over the course of the relationship
Relevant suppliers and other third parties are included in incident planning, response, and recovery activities
Supply chain security practices are integrated into cybersecurity and enterprise risk management programs, and their performance is monitored throughout the technology product and service life cycle
Cybersecurity supply chain risk management plans include provisions for activities that occur after the conclusion of a partnership or service agreement

categories.name: AI Organizational Context
categories.description: The organizational context for AI systems, including mission alignment, stakeholder expectations, and AI-specific legal, regulatory, and contractual requirements, is understood and managed.

subcategories.outcome: AI system purposes, intended uses, and business contexts are documented and aligned with organizational mission
Internal and external stakeholder expectations regarding AI system performance, safety, and ethics are understood and considered
Legal, regulatory, and contractual requirements specific to AI systems, including privacy, fairness, and transparency obligations, are understood and managed
AI system dependencies on data sources, third-party models, and infrastructure components are identified and documented

categories.name: AI Risk Management
categories.description: The organization's AI risk management priorities, constraints, risk tolerance, and appetite are established and used to support AI-related operational decisions.

subcategories.outcome: AI-specific risk tolerance levels are established based on system criticality, potential harm, and organizational context
AI risk assessment methodology addressing model risks, data risks, and adversarial threats is defined and applied
AI system risks are integrated into enterprise risk management processes and risk registers
AI risk communication processes are established to inform stakeholders of AI-related risks and mitigations

categories.name: AI Policy
categories.description: Organizational policies governing AI system development, deployment, and operation are established, communicated, and enforced.

subcategories.outcome: AI governance policies addressing development, deployment, monitoring, and retirement of AI systems are established
AI ethics guidelines covering fairness, transparency, accountability, and human oversight are documented and communicated
AI acceptable use policies defining permitted and prohibited uses of AI systems are communicated to all personnel
AI policy compliance is monitored and policy violations are addressed through established procedures

functions.name: Identify
functions.description: The organization's current cybersecurity risks are understood. Understanding its assets (e.g., data, hardware, software, systems, facilities, services, people), suppliers, and related cybersecurity risks enables an organization to prioritize its efforts consistent with its risk management strategy and the mission needs identified under GOVERN.

categories.name: Asset Management
categories.description: Assets (e.g., data, hardware, software, systems, facilities, services, people) that enable the organization to achieve business purposes are identified and managed consistent with their relative importance to organizational objectives and the organization's risk strategy.

subcategories.outcome: Inventories of hardware managed by the organization are maintained
Inventories of software, services, and systems managed by the organization are maintained
Representations of the organization's authorized network communication and internal and external network data flows are maintained
Inventories of services provided by suppliers are maintained
Assets are prioritized based on classification, criticality, resources, and impact on the mission
Roles and responsibilities for asset management are established, assigned, and communicated
Inventories of data and corresponding metadata for designated data types are maintained
Systems, hardware, software, services, and data are managed throughout their life cycles

categories.name: Improvement
categories.description: Improvements to organizational cybersecurity risk management processes, procedures and activities are identified across all CSF Functions.

subcategories.outcome: Improvements are identified from evaluations
Improvements are identified from security tests and exercises, including those done in coordination with suppliers and relevant third parties
Improvements are identified from execution of operational processes, procedures, and activities
Incident response plans and other cybersecurity plans that affect operations are established, communicated, maintained, and improved

categories.name: Risk Assessment
categories.description: The cybersecurity risk to the organization, assets, and individuals is understood by the organization.

subcategories.outcome: Vulnerabilities in assets are identified, validated, and recorded
Cyber threat intelligence is received from information sharing forums and sources
Internal and external threats to the organization are identified and recorded
Potential impacts and likelihoods of threats exploiting vulnerabilities are identified and recorded
Threats, vulnerabilities, likelihoods, and impacts are used to understand inherent risk and inform risk response prioritization
Risk responses are chosen, prioritized, planned, tracked, and communicated
Changes and exceptions are managed, assessed for risk impact, recorded, and tracked
Processes for receiving, analyzing, and responding to vulnerability disclosures are established
The authenticity and integrity of hardware and software are assessed prior to acquisition and use
Critical suppliers are assessed prior to acquisition

categories.name: AI Asset Management
categories.description: AI systems, models, datasets, and related components that enable the organization to achieve business purposes are identified and managed consistent with their relative importance and risk.

subcategories.outcome: Inventories of AI systems including their purposes, capabilities, and deployment contexts are maintained
AI models are cataloged with metadata including version, training data sources, performance characteristics, and known limitations
Training and inference datasets are inventoried with data lineage, quality assessments, and sensitivity classifications
AI system dependencies including third-party models, APIs, frameworks, and infrastructure components are documented

categories.name: AI Risk Assessment
categories.description: AI-specific cybersecurity risks to the organization, its assets, and individuals are identified and understood.

subcategories.outcome: AI-specific threats including adversarial attacks, model theft, and data poisoning are identified and recorded
AI vulnerability assessments covering model robustness, data integrity, and system security are conducted
AI impact assessments evaluating potential harm from system failures, biased outputs, or malicious manipulation are performed
AI risks are prioritized based on likelihood, impact, and alignment with organizational risk tolerance

categories.name: AI Vulnerability Management
categories.description: Vulnerabilities specific to AI systems, models, and data pipelines are identified, assessed, and managed.

subcategories.outcome: AI model vulnerabilities including adversarial example susceptibility, membership inference risks, and model extraction threats are identified
Adversarial attack vectors targeting AI systems are assessed and documented with potential impact analysis
Data poisoning risks in training pipelines and inference data streams are evaluated and monitored
AI supply chain vulnerabilities in pre-trained models, datasets, and ML frameworks are tracked and assessed

functions.name: Protect
functions.description: Safeguards to manage the organization's cybersecurity risks are used. Once assets and risks are identified and prioritized, PROTECT supports the ability to secure those assets to prevent or lower the likelihood and impact of adverse cybersecurity events, as well as to increase the likelihood and impact of taking advantage of opportunities.

categories.name: Identity Management, Authentication, and Access Control
categories.description: Access to physical and logical assets is limited to authorized users, services, and hardware and managed commensurate with the assessed risk of unauthorized access.

subcategories.outcome: Identities and credentials for authorized users, services, and hardware are managed by the organization
Identities are proofed and bound to credentials based on the context of interactions
Users, services, and hardware are authenticated
Identity assertions are protected, conveyed, and verified
Access permissions, entitlements, and authorizations are defined in a policy, managed, enforced, and reviewed, and incorporate the principles of least privilege and separation of duties
Physical access to assets is managed, monitored, and enforced commensurate with risk

categories.name: Awareness and Training
categories.description: The organization's personnel are provided with cybersecurity awareness and training so that they can perform their cybersecurity-related tasks.

subcategories.outcome: Personnel are provided with awareness and training so that they possess the knowledge and skills to perform general tasks with cybersecurity risks in mind
Individuals in specialized roles are provided with awareness and training so that they possess the knowledge and skills to perform relevant tasks with cybersecurity risks in mind

categories.name: Data Security
categories.description: Data are managed consistent with the organization's risk strategy to protect the confidentiality, integrity, and availability of information.

subcategories.outcome: The confidentiality, integrity, and availability of data-at-rest are protected
The confidentiality, integrity, and availability of data-in-transit are protected
The confidentiality, integrity, and availability of data-in-use are protected
Availability of critical services is protected against degradation or failure
Access permissions and authorizations are managed, incorporating the principles of least privilege and separation of duties
The integrity of software, firmware, and information is verified using integrity verification mechanisms
The development and testing environments are separate from production, and access to each is managed
Hardware integrity is protected, verified, and maintained
The confidentiality of backup data is protected
The confidentiality, integrity, and availability of data-in-use are protected
Backups of data are created, protected, maintained, and tested

categories.name: Information Protection Processes and Procedures
categories.description: Security policies, processes, and procedures are established, maintained, and applied to protect information and technology assets

subcategories.outcome: Policies, standards, procedures, and other guidance for protecting information systems and assets are established, maintained, and executed
System development lifecycle processes include security considerations
Configuration change control processes and procedures are in place and executed
Information system and asset configurations are established, documented, implemented, maintained, and reviewed
Policy and regulations regarding the physical operating environment for organizational assets are met
Secure software development practices are integrated, and their performance is monitored throughout the software development life cycle
The organization's security testing program includes the use of various testing techniques, and findings are remediated
Incident response plans and other cybersecurity plans that affect operations are established, communicated, maintained, and improved
Response and recovery plans are tested and improved

categories.name: Technology Infrastructure Resilience
categories.description: Security architectures are managed with the organization's risk strategy to protect asset confidentiality, integrity, and availability, and organizational resilience.

subcategories.outcome: Networks and environments are protected from unauthorized logical access and usage
The organization's technology assets are protected from environmental threats
Mechanisms are implemented to achieve resilience requirements in normal and adverse situations
Adequate resource capacity to ensure availability is maintained

categories.name: Maintenance
categories.description: Maintenance and repairs of organizational assets are performed and logged, with approved and controlled tools

subcategories.outcome: System maintenance, troubleshooting, and repair are performed using approved and controlled tools
Remote system maintenance and diagnostics activities are approved, logged, and performed in a manner that prevents unauthorized access

categories.name: Platform Security
categories.description: The hardware, software (e.g., firmware, operating systems, applications), and services of physical and virtual platforms are managed consistent with the organization's risk strategy to protect their confidentiality, integrity, and availability.

subcategories.outcome: Configuration management practices are established and applied
Software is maintained, replaced, and removed commensurate with risk
Hardware is maintained, replaced, and removed commensurate with risk
Log records are generated and made available for continuous monitoring
Installation and execution of unauthorized software are prevented
Secure software development practices are integrated, and their performance is monitored throughout the software development life cycle

categories.name: Protective Technology
categories.description: Technical security solutions are implemented and managed to ensure the security and resilience of systems and assets

subcategories.outcome: System and network security architectures are established, documented, maintained, and reviewed
System security configurations are established, documented, implemented, maintained, and reviewed
System security capabilities (e.g., logging, monitoring, alerting) are implemented, managed, and improved
System and network communications are protected
Mechanisms are implemented to achieve resilience requirements during normal operations and in adverse situations

categories.name: AI Access and Authentication
categories.description: Access to AI systems, models, and data is limited to authorized users, services, and applications and managed commensurate with AI-specific risks.

subcategories.outcome: Access to AI systems and their components is controlled based on defined roles and least privilege principles
Authentication mechanisms for AI model access ensure only authorized users and services can invoke AI capabilities
API access to AI services is secured with rate limiting, authentication, and input validation
Privileged operations on AI systems including model updates and configuration changes require elevated authorization

categories.name: AI Data Security
categories.description: Data used by AI systems including training data, model parameters, and inference data are protected throughout their lifecycle.

subcategories.outcome: Training data is protected at rest with encryption and access controls appropriate to data sensitivity
Model weights, parameters, and configurations are secured against unauthorized access and modification
AI data in transit including inference requests, responses, and model updates is encrypted
AI data lifecycle including retention, archival, and secure disposal is managed according to policy

categories.name: AI Model Security
categories.description: AI models are protected from extraction, tampering, and unauthorized use throughout their lifecycle.

subcategories.outcome: Models are protected from extraction attacks through query rate limiting, output perturbation, and monitoring
Model integrity is validated through checksums, signatures, and provenance verification before deployment
Model deployment pipelines are secured with access controls, approval workflows, and audit logging
Model versioning is controlled with rollback capabilities and change tracking for all model updates

functions.name: Detect
functions.description: Possible cybersecurity attacks and compromises are found and analyzed. DETECT enables timely discovery and analysis of anomalies, indicators of compromise, and other potentially adverse cybersecurity events that may indicate that cybersecurity attacks and incidents are occurring.

categories.name: Adverse Event Analysis
categories.description: Anomalies, indicators of compromise, and other potentially adverse events are analyzed to characterize the events and detect cybersecurity incidents.

subcategories.outcome: Networks, systems, and assets are monitored to identify potentially malicious activity
Potentially adverse events are analyzed to better understand associated activities
Information is correlated from multiple sources
The estimated impact and scope of adverse events are understood
Incident alerting and reporting processes are established
Information on adverse events is provided to authorized staff and tools
Cyber threat intelligence and other contextual information are integrated into the analysis
Incidents are declared when adverse events meet the defined incident criteria

categories.name: Continuous Monitoring
categories.description: Assets are monitored to find anomalies, indicators of compromise, and other potentially adverse events.

subcategories.outcome: Networks and network services are monitored to find potentially adverse events
The physical environment is monitored to find potentially adverse events
Personnel activity and technology usage are monitored to find potentially adverse events
Network communications are monitored
External service provider activities on the organization's networks are monitored
External service provider activities and services are monitored to find potentially adverse events
Monitoring for unauthorized personnel, hardware, connections, devices, and software is performed
Vulnerability assessments are performed and findings remediated according to organizational priorities
Computing hardware and software, runtime environments, and their data are monitored to find potentially adverse events

categories.name: AI Continuous Monitoring
categories.description: AI systems are continuously monitored to detect anomalies, performance degradation, and security events.

subcategories.outcome: AI system behavior including input patterns, output distributions, and decision patterns is monitored for anomalies
Model performance metrics including accuracy, latency, and resource utilization are tracked against baselines
Data drift in input features and concept drift in model predictions are detected and alerted
AI audit logs capturing access, queries, responses, and configuration changes are maintained and reviewed

categories.name: AI Anomaly and Event Analysis
categories.description: Anomalous AI system behaviors and security events are analyzed to characterize potential threats and incidents.

subcategories.outcome: Anomalous AI outputs including unexpected predictions, biased results, and hallucinations are detected and investigated
AI security events including unusual access patterns, suspicious queries, and potential attacks are analyzed
Model drift patterns are analyzed to distinguish normal evolution from potential manipulation or poisoning
AI incident correlation links events across multiple AI systems and security tools to identify coordinated attacks

categories.name: AI Adversarial Detection
categories.description: Adversarial attacks and malicious activities targeting AI systems are detected and characterized.

subcategories.outcome: Adversarial inputs including evasion attacks, prompt injections, and jailbreak attempts are detected
Model manipulation attempts including model extraction, inversion, and backdoor activation are identified
Data poisoning attempts in training pipelines and feedback loops are detected through data validation
AI-enabled attacks including AI-generated phishing, deepfakes, and automated exploitation are recognized

functions.name: Respond
functions.description: Actions regarding a detected cybersecurity incident are taken. RESPOND supports the ability to contain the effects of cybersecurity incidents. Outcomes within this Function cover incident management, analysis, mitigation, reporting, and communication.

categories.name: Incident Analysis
categories.description: Investigations are conducted to ensure effective response and support forensics and recovery activities.

subcategories.outcome: The impact and scope of incidents are understood
Evidence related to incidents is collected, analyzed, and preserved
Analysis is performed to establish what has taken place during an incident and the root cause of the incident
The estimated impact of incidents guides response activities
Response activities are documented
Actions performed during an investigation are recorded, and the records' integrity and provenance are preserved
Incident data and metadata are collected, and their integrity and provenance are preserved
An incident's magnitude is estimated and validated

categories.name: Incident Response Reporting and Communication
categories.description: Response activities are coordinated with internal and external stakeholders as required by laws, regulations, or policies.

subcategories.outcome: A communication plan for incident response that addresses roles, responsibilities, and communication protocols is established and maintained
Internal and external stakeholders are notified of incidents
Information is shared with designated internal and external stakeholders
Coordination with internal and external stakeholders occurs consistent with response plans
Voluntary information sharing with external stakeholders occurs to achieve broader cybersecurity situational awareness

categories.name: Incident Management
categories.description: Responses to detected cybersecurity incidents are managed.

subcategories.outcome: The incident response plan is executed in coordination with relevant third parties once an incident is declared
Incident reports are triaged and validated
Incidents are categorized and prioritized
Incidents are escalated or elevated as needed
The criteria for initiating incident recovery are applied

categories.name: Incident Mitigation
categories.description: Activities are performed to prevent expansion of an event and mitigate its effects.

subcategories.outcome: Incidents are contained
Incidents are eradicated
Recovery activities are performed during incidents

categories.name: Response Planning
categories.description: Response activities are planned, managed, and coordinated with internal and external stakeholders

subcategories.outcome: A response plan that addresses roles, responsibilities, and communication protocols during and after an incident is developed and implemented
System capabilities and organizational processes that support incident response are established
Response plan and associated communications are communicated to impacted stakeholders
Coordination with internal and external stakeholders occurs during incident response activities
Response plans incorporate lessons learned from previous incidents and exercises

categories.name: AI Incident Management
categories.description: AI-specific incident response activities are coordinated and managed to contain and remediate AI system compromises.

subcategories.outcome: AI incident response procedures addressing model compromise, data poisoning, and adversarial attacks are established and tested
AI incident escalation paths defining when to involve AI specialists, executives, and external parties are defined
AI system isolation capabilities allow rapid containment of compromised models without full service disruption
AI incident documentation captures attack vectors, affected systems, response actions, and business impact

categories.name: AI Incident Analysis
categories.description: AI-specific incidents are analyzed to determine root cause, impact, and required remediation actions.

subcategories.outcome: AI incident root cause analysis identifies attack methods, vulnerabilities exploited, and system weaknesses
AI model failure analysis determines whether failures result from attacks, drift, bugs, or environmental factors
AI impact assessment evaluates effects on model integrity, data confidentiality, and business operations
AI incident lessons learned are captured and shared to improve future prevention and response capabilities

categories.name: AI Model Threat Response
categories.description: Responses to threats targeting AI models are executed to contain damage and restore secure operations.

subcategories.outcome: Compromised models are contained through isolation, access revocation, and traffic redirection to backup systems
Model rollback procedures restore previous known-good model versions when current versions are compromised
Adversarial attack mitigation including input filtering, output sanitization, and detection enhancement is applied
AI service continuity is maintained through failover systems, degraded operation modes, and manual overrides

functions.name: Recover
functions.description: Assets and operations affected by a cybersecurity incident are restored. RECOVER supports timely restoration of normal operations to reduce the effects of cybersecurity incidents and enable appropriate communication during recovery efforts.

categories.name: Incident Recovery Communication
categories.description: Restoration activities are coordinated with internal and external parties.

subcategories.outcome: Recovery activities are coordinated with internal and external stakeholders (e.g. coordinating centers, Internet Service Providers, owners of attacking systems, victims, other CSIRTs, and vendors)
Internal and external stakeholders understand their roles and order of operations during recovery activities
Recovery activities and progress in restoring operational capabilities are communicated to designated internal and external stakeholders
Public updates on incident recovery are shared using approved methods and messaging

categories.name: Improvements
categories.description: Recovery planning and processes are improved by incorporating lessons learned and effective practices into future activities

subcategories.outcome: Recovery lessons learned are incorporated into updated response and recovery plans
Recovery strategies and lessons learned are updated based on evaluation of previous recovery activities and changing threat and vulnerability landscapes

categories.name: Incident Recovery Plan Execution
categories.description: Restoration activities are performed to ensure operational availability of systems and services affected by cybersecurity incidents.

subcategories.outcome: The incident recovery portion of the incident response plan is executed once initiated from the incident response process
Recovery actions are selected, scoped, prioritized, and performed
The integrity of backups and other restoration assets is verified before using them for restoration
Critical mission functions and cybersecurity risk management are considered to establish post-incident operational norms
The integrity of restored assets is verified, systems and services are restored, and normal operating status is confirmed
The end of incident recovery is declared based on criteria, and incident-related documentation is completed

categories.name: AI Recovery Planning
categories.description: Recovery plans for AI systems are established, tested, and maintained to ensure rapid restoration of AI capabilities.

subcategories.outcome: AI system recovery plans addressing model restoration, data recovery, and service continuity are established
AI backup procedures including model snapshots, training data archives, and configuration backups are documented and executed
AI recovery testing validates restoration procedures and recovery time objectives through regular exercises
AI system recovery is integrated with overall business continuity and disaster recovery planning

categories.name: AI Retraining and Learning
categories.description: Procedures for retraining AI models and incorporating lessons learned from incidents into improved AI systems are established.

subcategories.outcome: Model retraining procedures including data preparation, training protocols, and validation criteria are defined
Clean data restoration processes ensure training data integrity after poisoning or contamination incidents
Model validation post-recovery confirms restored models meet performance, safety, and security requirements
Recovery improvements from incident analysis are incorporated into updated AI recovery plans and procedures

cyber_ai_profile.description: The NIST Cyber AI Profile (NIST IR 8596) maps AI-specific cybersecurity considerations to the CSF 2.0 framework. It focuses on three key areas: Secure (protecting AI systems), Defend (using AI for cybersecurity), and Thwart (defending against AI-enabled threats).

focus_areas.name: Secure AI Systems
focus_areas.description: Protecting AI systems and their components from cybersecurity threats, ensuring the confidentiality, integrity, and availability of AI models, data, and infrastructure.

focus_areas.name: Defend with AI
focus_areas.description: Leveraging AI capabilities to enhance cybersecurity defenses, including threat detection, incident response, and security automation.

focus_areas.name: Thwart AI-Enabled Threats
focus_areas.description: Defending against adversarial use of AI, including AI-generated attacks, deepfakes, automated reconnaissance, and AI-powered social engineering.

ai_specific_outcomes.ai_extension: AI system risks including model vulnerabilities, data poisoning, and adversarial attacks are included in risk management objectives
Risks from AI components in the supply chain (pre-trained models, training data, ML frameworks) are assessed and monitored
Inventories of AI/ML models, training datasets, and AI-enabled services are maintained
AI-specific vulnerabilities including adversarial examples, model extraction, and membership inference are identified
AI-enabled threats including automated attacks and AI-generated content are identified and recorded
Training data, model weights, and AI system configurations are protected at rest
Model inference requests and responses are protected in transit
Personnel are trained to recognize AI-generated threats including deepfakes and AI-powered phishing
AI systems are monitored for anomalous behavior indicating adversarial attacks or model drift
AI/ML model behavior, input patterns, and output distributions are monitored for adversarial manipulation
AI-enhanced analytics are used to analyze and correlate security events
AI-assisted analysis tools support incident investigation and root cause analysis
